'''Edvard Rusjan''' (6 June 1886 – 9 January 1911)<ref name="Rusjan" /><ref name="Sitar" /> was a [[Slovenes|Slovenian]] flight pioneer and airplane constructor. He died in an airplane crash in [[Belgrade]].<ref name="Rusjan">{{cite encyclopedia |url=http://nl.ijs.si/fedora/get/sbl:2704/VIEW/ |title=Rusjan Edvard |encyclopedia=Slovenski biografski leksikon |editors=Vide Ogrin, Petra (electronic ed.). Cankar, Izidor et al. (printed ed.) |year=1925–1991 (printed ed.). 2009 (electronic ed.) |language=Slovenian|last=Mesesnel |first=France |isbn=978-961-268-001-5}}</ref><ref>http://www.vazduhoplovnetradicijesrbije.rs/index.php/clancivlepojevica/160-m-mercep-i-e-rusjan</ref>
== Biography == Rusjan was born in [[Trieste]],<ref name="Rusjan" /> then the major port of [[Austria-Hungary]] (now in [[Italy]]). His parents were both natives of the [[Gorizia and Gradisca]] region: his father, Franc Rusjan, was a [[Slovenes|Slovene]], and his mother, Grazia Cabas, was [[Friuli-Venezia Giulia|Friulan]].<ref>{{cite book |title=Brata Edvard in Josip Rusjan iz Gorice: začetkí motornega letenja med Slovenci |first=Srečko |last=Gombač |year=2004 |publisher=Puhek}}</ref> Rusjan spent his childhood and adolescence in [[Gorizia]], in the suburb of [[Pristava, Nova Gorica|Rafut]].
In his youth, he became a professional bicyclist, and designed his own bicycle models, together with his brother Josip Rusjan. He was also member of the [[Sokol]] gymnastic association.
He made his first flight on 25 November 1909, near Gorizia, in [[Eda I]], a biplane of his own design. Eda was Edvard's nickname, given from his mother. <ref name="Rusjan" /><ref name="RS-Rusjan">{{cite web|url=http://www.ukom.gov.si/en/media_relations/background_information/science_and_technology/edvard_rusjan_pioneer_of_slovene_aviation/|last=|first=|title=Edvard Rusjan, Pioneer of Slovene Aviation|date=|publisher=Republic of Slovenia – Government Communication Office|accessdate=11 September 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140423044448/http://www.ukom.gov.si/en/media_relations/background_information/science_and_technology/edvard_rusjan_pioneer_of_slovene_aviation/|archivedate=23 April 2014|df=}}</ref>
The flight was covered {{convert|60|m|abbr=on}} and reached a height of {{convert|2|m|abbr=on}}. On 29 November 1909, he flew {{convert|600|m|abbr=on}} at an altitude of {{convert|12|m|abbr=on}}. The original design was followed by several improved versions. He moved to a hangar near [[Miren]] south of Gorizia.
Rusjan first attended a public flight event with the model EDA V on 6 December 1909, when his aircraft broke apart at landing.<ref name="Rusjan" /> In June 1910, he tried the model EDA V, which enabled him to fly 40 meters above the ground and overfly the whole [[Miren]] Field. [[File:Rusjanovo letalo Eda.JPG|thumb|Replica of Rusjan airplane [[Eda V]]]] The brothers Rusjan ran out of finance for the construction of EDA VII. In 1910 Edvard Rusjan met the businessman of Serbian origin [[Mihailo Merćep|Mihajlo Merćep]], who offered him financial help for his endeavors. The same year, the brothers moved to [[Zagreb]], Croatia, when they started a project of airplane construction on larger scale. In November 1910, they constructed a new model.<ref name="Rusjan" />
In January 1911, Edvard and Josip Rusjan went on a promotional tour through the [[Balkan]] cities. During a flight in [[Belgrade]], [[Serbia]] on 9 January 1911 a strong wind broke a wing of Edvard's aeroplane and it dived into a railway embankment near the [[Belgrade Fortress]] in a fatal crash.<ref name="Sitar">{{cite book |title=Edvard Rusjan |first=Sandi |last=Sitar |year=1989 |page=72 |publisher=Partizanska knjiga |id={{COBISS|ID=7780352}}}}</ref><ref name="RS-Rusjan"/> His funeral was attended by a large crowd of about 14,000 people.
He is interred at [[Belgrade's New Cemetery]], lot 15, grave 343.
== Legacy == The [[Maribor Edvard Rusjan Airport]] and asteroid [[19633 Rusjan]] are named after him. The commercial and business center ''Eda Center'' in [[Nova Gorica]] is dedicated to Rusjan's memory.
One of the [[McDonnell Douglas DC-10|DC-10]] in the [[Jugoslovenski Aerotransport|JAT]] fleet was named after Edvard Rusjan<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.taxiways.de/DC-10/46988_278.html|title=MC DONNELL - DOUGLAS DC - 10|website=www.taxiways.de|access-date=2017-01-31}}</ref>.
